node.title: Error in Building MOOSE
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I am running into an error message, when trying to run the command:
make -j 6
Traceback (most recent call last):
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::dir_name(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::HITNodeView::dataabi:cxx11 const'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::NodeView::data[abi:cxx11]() const' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::Value::operator[](std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::HITNodeView::to_string[abi:cxx11](bool*) const' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::strip_quotes(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::buildCompletionObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, int, int, int, int, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, int, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&, bool, bool, int)' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::RPCStringToObject(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::HITNodeView::last_as_string[abi:cxx11](bool*) const' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::DataObject::operator[](std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::HITNodeView::first_child_by_name(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&) const' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::buildLocationObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, int, int, int, int)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::HITNodeView::path[abi:cxx11]() const' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::buildDocumentSymbolObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, int, bool, int, int, int, int, int, int, int, int)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::objectToRPCString(wasp::DataObject&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> >&, std::ostream&)' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::buildTextEditObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, int, int, int, int, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::file_exists(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits<char>, std::allocator<char> > const&)' /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to wasp::lsp::buildDiagnosticObject(wasp::DataObject&, std::ostream&, int, int, int, int, int, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&)'
/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/framework/libmoose-opt.so: undefined reference to `wasp::HITNodeView::child_count_by_name(std::__cxx11::basic_string<char, std::char_traits, std::allocator > const&, unsigned long) const'
collect2: error: ld returned 1 exit status
make: *** [/usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/test/moose_test-opt] Error 1
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
This looks like your version of moose and wasp are not in sync.
Are you using the conda binaries for the dependencies?
If so the diagnostics script in moose/scripts should give you more information
Guillaume
I am using GCC compiler and building the stack manually.

Can you print out the results of the diagnostic script? Sometimes it shows us some information that proves useful:
cd /usr/apps/sreihani/projects/moose/scripts
./diagnostics.sh

I was able to find a solution for the issue and compiled the moose successfully. I think the order of modules loaded to the local environment is critical as there might be a conflict between some of them that can create Tcl command execution, However, I have added the output of diagnostic script below. If you have any recommendations, please let me know.
####################################################################################################
Influential Environment Variables
CC=gcc
CONDA_CHANNEL=https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
CURL_CA_BUNDLE=
F95=gfortran
LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib:/usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/lib/gcc/x86_64-pc-linux-gnu/9.2.0:/usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/lib64:/usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/lib:/usr/local/src/git/2.19.0/lib:/usr/local/python/3.9.16/lib
MODULESHOME=/usr/share/Modules
MOOSE_JOBS=6
PATH=/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin:/usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/bin:/usr/local/cmake/3.18.4/bin:/usr/local/src/git/2.19.0/bin:/usr/local/python/3.9.16/bin:/usr/local/dos2unix/7.4.0/bin:/usr/lib64/qt-3.3/bin:/usr/local/perlbrew/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=
SSL_CERT_FILE=
####################################################################################################
Compiler(s) (CC CXX FC F77 F90):
which $CC; /usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/bin/gcc
$CC --version; gcc (GCC) 9.2.0
FAIL: gcc appears not to be an MPI wrapper
CXX     not set
FC      not set
F77     not set
F90     not set
FAIL: One or more compiler environment variables not set, or set incorrectly
####################################################################################################
Python Sanity Checks
/usr/bin/env python3 --version; (reporting as: Python 3.9.16) matches
which python3 python;
/usr/local/python/3.9.16/bin/python3 --version; == Python 3.9.16
Python 2.7.5
FAIL: Python 2.7.5
/usr/bin/python --version (reporting as )) != Python 3.9.16
This will likely result in the TestHarness failing. Or WASP/HIT parsing errors.
####################################################################################################
Python Modules (TestHarness, run-ability)
WARNING: missing module(s): jinja2
Either install the above packages, or perhaps you have yet
to activate the moose environment: conda activate moose
Missing 'warning' Python modules may cause miscellaneous runtime issues.
WARNING: One or more Python issues present.
checks FAILED

If the above report is based on the final set of module load commands completed... I would say MOOSE will ultimately fail to run properly.
Not sure if you've already corrected all the issues based on the diagnostic report, but they look simple enough:
export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx FC=mpif90 F90=mpif90 F77=mpif77
alias python=python3
./diagnostics.sh
See note below about alias python=python3
You can ignore the bit about jinja2 not being available. You'll run into some minor things that might fail. But ultimately not needed.
Looks like my diagnostic script isn't properly understanding how to parse Python 2.7x. Its a bit difficult to read, but basically the error is thus:
Some scripts out in the wild which we depend on (like PETSc's configure scripts) may include shebangs that begin with #!/usr/bin/env python instead of the new proper way: #!/usr/bin/env python3. If this is still the case, your system may incur an issue due to the entire MOOSE dependency stack not using the same Python version throughout the build/run process.
Because this is an HPC system for which you probably don't have admin rights for, I think the sollution which might work, is to create an alias for python to python3:
alias python=python3
This is only good for the terminal session you are running in (you'll need to perform this each and every time you start a terminal/log in). I am curious if after setting this, does diagnostic.sh pass.

Thanks for posting! I am constantly trying to improve the diagnostic script. It is meant to be a helper tool to figure out what is needed in order to fix the more common issues we answer on Discussions :)
The bit about:
CXX not set
FC not set
F77 not set
F90 not set

FAIL: One or more compiler environment variables not set, or set incorrectly

for example, I should be including what needs to be done
F90 not set

FAIL: One or more compiler environment variables not set, or set incorrectly

To solve this issue, you must set the above variables to point to your MPI wrapper:

export CC=mpicc CXX=mpicxx

etc etc

Jason,
Here is the output of diagnostics test after what you suggested. It seems diagnostics.sh passes the compiler section but fails on python. However, python as an alias deploys python3. In my environment PYTHONPATH directs to 3.9.16. Can this help resolve the potential issue you mentioned?

Influential Environment Variables
CC=mpicc
CONDA_CHANNEL=https://conda.software.inl.gov/public
CURL_CA_BUNDLE=
CXX=mpicxx
F77=mpif77
F90=mpif90
F95=gfortran
FC=mpif90

MODULESHOME=/usr/share/Modules
MOOSE_JOBS=6
PATH=/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin:/usr/local/gcc/alt/9.2.0/bin:/usr/local/cmake/3.18.4/bin:/usr/local/src/git/2.19.0/bin:/usr/local/python/3.9.16/bin:/usr/local/dos2unix/7.4.0/bin:/usr/lib64/qt-3.3/bin:/usr/local/perlbrew/bin:/usr/local/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/sbin:/usr/sbin:/sbin
REQUESTS_CA_BUNDLE=
SSL_CERT_FILE=
####################################################################################################
Compiler(s) (CC CXX FC F77 F90):
which $CC; /usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin/mpicc
$CC --version; gcc (GCC) 9.2.0
$CC -show; gcc -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/include -pthread -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -lmpi
which $CXX; /usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin/mpicxx
$CXX --version; g++ (GCC) 9.2.0
$CXX -show; g++ -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/include -pthread -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -lmpi
which $FC; /usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin/mpif90
$FC --version; GNU Fortran (GCC) 9.2.0
$FC -show; gfortran -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/include -pthread -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -lmpi_usempif08 -lmpi_usempi_ignore_tkr -lmpi_mpifh -lmpi
which $F77; /usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin/mpif77
$F77 --version; GNU Fortran (GCC) 9.2.0
$F77 -show; gfortran -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/include -pthread -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -lmpi_usempif08 -lmpi_usempi_ignore_tkr -lmpi_mpifh -lmpi
which $F90; /usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/bin/mpif90
$F90 --version; GNU Fortran (GCC) 9.2.0
$F90 -show; gfortran -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/include -pthread -I/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -L/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/lib64 -Wl,-rpath -Wl,/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -Wl,--enable-new-dtags -L/usr/local/mpi/rh7/openmpi/4.1.1/gcc/9.2.0/lib -lmpi_usempif08 -lmpi_usempi_ignore_tkr -lmpi_mpifh -lmpi
OK
####################################################################################################
Python Sanity Checks
/usr/bin/env python3 --version; (reporting as: Python 3.9.16) matches
which python3 python;
/usr/local/python/3.9.16/bin/python3 --version; == Python 3.9.16
Python 2.7.5
FAIL: Python 2.7.5
/usr/bin/python --version (reporting as )) != Python 3.9.16
This will likely result in the TestHarness failing. Or WASP/HIT parsing errors.
####################################################################################################
Python Modules (TestHarness, run-ability)
WARNING: missing module(s): jinja2
Either install the above packages, or perhaps you have yet
to activate the moose environment: conda activate moose
Missing 'warning' Python modules may cause miscellaneous runtime issues.
WARNING: One or more Python issues present.
checks FAILED

I was wondering if aliasing would work. I am betting all the logic I have in the diagnostic script is ignoring the fact it should be looking at python3 instead.
I would ignore this for now, and continue to build the stack. If and when Python 2.7 becomes an issue, we will look into that.

Jason,
Our admin created a link for python to make sure that potential issue would not occur. Now diagnostics.sh passes the test,

these are all tied to hit, the parser
so it s safe to say it wont affect results

Thanks.
I am wondering if there is any other tool to open exit files of moose other than VSCode recommended on the web?

input files can be opened with any text editor
output files, it depends on the type. We use mostly paraview for exodus and excel or paraview for CSVs

Sure, I know that. I was referring to this page: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/development/VSCode.html
In the videos of MOOSE workshops, VSCode is recommended for visualizing the output binary files.
we dont use binary for output, expect for some versions of checkpoints
For a tutorial test, moose generated two files (step1_out.e & step1_in.e). vi editor shows both have binary content. Am I correct? Also, does output files have a specific format & name convention?
these are exodus files, you can open them with paraview

I imagine so, but I can't tell for certain. If you would scroll back a ways in the terminal that produces this error, you will see details for each error.
You can also run just one of these tests:
./run_tests --re=misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist
And copy/paste the error. There are two parts to every erring test. This page describes it best: https://mooseframework.inl.gov/help/troubleshooting.html#failingtests

Here is the output for the command:
./run_tests --re=misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist

^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0mWorking Directory: /usr/apps/SoTeRiA/sreihani/projects/moose/test/tests/misc/hit_cli
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0mRunning command: ./hit_wrapper.py gold/parameter_does_not_exist find -v Kernels/\*/variable input1.i input2.i
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0mFailed to locate hit executable.
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0m
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0m################################################################################
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0mTester failed, reason: CODE 1
^[[31mmisc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist: ^[[0m
misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist ^[[90m...................................................^[[0m ^[[31mFAILED (CODE 1)^[[0m


Final Test Results:
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
misc/hit_cli.find/parameter_does_not_exist ^[[90m...................................................^[[0m ^[[31mFAILED (CODE 1)^[[0m
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 tests in 4.1 seconds. Average test time 0.0 seconds, maximum test time 0.0 seconds.
^[[1m0 passed^[[0m, ^[[1m0 skipped^[[0m, ^[[1m0 pending^[[0m, ^[[1m^[[31m1 FAILED^[[0m
Thats weird to me... I would imagine "hit" missing would result in a great many more tests failing... @GiudGiud  any ideas?

node.title: Initial conditions with TimedSubdomainModifier
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi, I am new to MOOSE, but run into some unexpected results.
My problem is related to a welding simulation, demonstrated with a simpler problem here. I have divided my domain into two subdomains (left and right with IDs 0 and 2 ). The right subdomain is not active at the start of the simulation. I am increasing the temperature on the boundary between the two subdomains to 1000. Next, I want to activate the right block with an initial value of 1000 and deactivate the boundary condition, so that the heat can flow from the right domain to the left domain, i.e. the temperature field should even out. I activate the right region by using a TimedSubdomainModifier to move the domain to the block with ID 1, which has an initial condition of 1000, and deactivate the boundary condition (see input file at bottom post).
However, in this case, the initial condition does not seem to be applied. This is the last increment before the activation of the right region (at t=10) :

This is the increment after the activation:

Furthermore, it seems like some boundary condition is now applied to the right side, as this is at a later time increment:

The behavior is different, but still not as expected, if I set the execute_on parameter of the TimedSubdomainModifier to TIMESTEP_END. In this case the initial condition is applied, but the temperature in that region does not evolve. This is the result at a later time increment:

Additionally the small cold region, which is just in the left domain, is introduced.
Any ideas what I am doing wrong? Or is going wrong in MOOSE?
Here is my input file:
[Mesh]
  [generated]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 40
    ny = 10
    xmax = 40
    ymax = 10
  []
  [subdomains]
    type = ParsedSubdomainMeshGenerator
    input = generated
    combinatorial_geometry = 'x > 20.0'
    block_id = 2
  []
  [middle_sideset]
    type = SideSetsBetweenSubdomainsGenerator
    input = subdomains
    new_boundary = 'middle'
    primary_block = 0
    paired_block = 2
  []

  add_subdomain_ids = 1
[]

[Variables]
  [temp]
    order = first
    family = LAGRANGE
    block = '0 1'
  []
[]

[ICs]
    [base_ic]
        type = ConstantIC
        variable = temp
        value = 20
        block = 0
    []
    [weld_ic]
        type = ConstantIC
        variable = temp
        value = 1000
        block = 1
    []
[]

[Kernels]
  [heat_conduction]
      type = HeatConduction
      variable = temp
      block = '0 1'
  []
  [heat_timederivative]
      type = HeatConductionTimeDerivative
      variable = temp
      block = '0 1'
  []
[]

[Materials]
    [thermal]
        type = HeatConductionMaterial
        thermal_conductivity = 0.048
        specific_heat = 0.45
    []
    [density]
        type = GenericConstantMaterial
        prop_names = 'density'
        prop_values = 0.0078
    []
[]

[BCs]
  active = 'temp_middle'
  [temp_middle]
    type = FunctionDirichletBC
    variable = temp
    boundary = 'middle'
    function = '20 + 980 * t/10'
  []
[]

[Controls]
    active = 'disableheating'
    [disableheating]
      type = ConditionalFunctionEnableControl
      conditional_function = 't >= 10'
      disable_objects = 'BCs::temp_middle'
      enable_objects = ''
      execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
    []
[]

[UserObjects]
    active = 'insert'
   [insert]
       type = 'TimedSubdomainModifier'
       times =       '10'
       blocks_from = '2'
       blocks_to =   '1'
       execute_on = 'INITIAL TIMESTEP_BEGIN'
       apply_initial_conditions = true
   []
[]

[Problem]
  type = FEProblem
  kernel_coverage_check = false
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 50
  dt = 1
  solve_type = "NEWTON"
  petsc_options_iname = '-pc_type'
  petsc_options_value = 'lu'
  l_tol = 1.0e-6
  nl_rel_tol = 1.0e-4
  nl_abs_tol = 1.0e-4
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = true
[]

Hello
We actually just changed (wednesday night, released mid Thursday) the behavior of the subdomain modifiers with regards to initial conditions. You probably should update so we are looking at the same simulations.
The initial condition should be applied properly now.
The default bounday condition is 0 flux. Since the BC was applied on the middle and is then turned off, I think that's what you should see
Thank you! Indeed it is behaving as expected now.

node.title: Error with Make
node.bodyText:
Hi @GiudGiud
I am having an error while trying to use the make command to compile MOOSE. The error that I am getting is:
Makefile:55: jfs5687/work/moose_directories/moose//framework/app.mk: No such file or directory
make: *** No rule to make target 'jfs5687/work/moose_directories/moose//framework/app.mk'.  Stop.

I am unsure how to proceed. Any help is appreciated.
Thanks

Hello
Is the moose folder under moose_directories full? Did it clone properly? Do you have access permissions to it?
It seems it's missing a file. Can you navigate there and find app.mk?

Yes, I can navigate to find app.mk in the moose folder within moose_directories. I believe that it cloned properly. The make command was running at one point with a different error, but it has since stopped and only given me the output I posted.
weird. did you modify the Makefile? did you set MOOSE_DIR or another relevant environment vriable?
I did not modify the Makefile. I do not think that I set any environment variable.
maybe save all your work with git commit in both myApp and moose, then use git clean -Xfd to clean those two repos and try a clean build

node.title: loop over nodal variable values of current element in computeQpProperties()
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
hi there, i have a material property whose local value need to be modified according to the surrounding nodal variable value. In one element, before i determine the value of this material property at the quadpoint, i should loop over all the node of the current element and check if the nodal variable value meet the requirement. But i don't know how to implement this, could you give me some advice? Thanks!

Hello
From the current element attribute, you can get the list of nodes.
Then you can use either getNodalValue or the NodalArg (see MooseFunctor.h) to get the nodal values of the variable.
Guillaume
It works. Thank you！

node.title: Transition from libmesh to MFEM
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
I watched this presentation: Multiscale, Multiphysics Simulation Through Application Composition Using MOOSE - Derek Gaston. At the end of the presentation, Mr Gaston talks about tansitioning from libmesh to MFEM. I've check all the branches and didn't find any MFEM implementation.
I wanted to know if it's in development and if it's a closed source version of MOOSE?
@friedmud
any update?

I dont think this is the plan anymore.
@lindsayad do we have info we can share for the plan to leverage GPUs?

We are finalizing our recommendation to DOE about what path we want to choose for GPU acceleration. MFEM is one option. We should have a recommendation within the next few days. However, even once that recommendation has been made, it's far from a done deal. Let's say we do decide to transition to MFEM as a finite element backend, at least for GPU-based computations. It's possible that as we perform the transition we run into some showstopper which we don't yet foresee. Mechanical contact is a big unknown, as an example

node.title: Outputting a material property as a vector
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hi all,
I am trying to output a material property as a vector to store all of the quadrature point values on an element.
I want to output this to Exodus.
It is unclear to me what property type template I should use for the material property. I cannot find examples of a vector or moosearray type material property.
Any insight would be appreciated; thank you.

Hello
~If you want to visualize it as a vector in paraview, just make sure you output each component, using for example a MaterialRealVectorAUx to 3 variables named with the _x _y and _z suffix
For example:
aaa_x., aaa_y and aaa_z~
So creating 4 properties for each _qp would essentially give the same result? Assuming they are named properly
oh nevermind I misread
Also, I did find vector material properties, but I am unsure of how to initialize/output them properly
what type is your material property right now? Is it a vector (RealVectorValue)? or Real

I am trying to output a material property as a vector to store all of the quadrature point values on an element.
I want to output this to Exodus.

what for? Exodus is for visualization. If you want to visualize a material property, you project it onto a variable using an auxkernel, such as the MaterialRealAux
If you want to look at qp values, this object will output them to CSV
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/vectorpostprocessors/ElementMaterialSampler.html
I am working on a project where I need the quadrature point information on each element for certain material properties. They need to be part of the data in the exodus file.
I can just make a material property for each qp for each element
You could make a custom auxkernel, modifying the MaterialRealVectorAux to output only 1 _qp at a time to each variable
One variable for each _qp index on every element
That's a good idea as well, thanks!
Well actually, MaterialRealVectorAux already has the option to specify the quad point

node.title: Regarding using Anisotropic heat conduction modules
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to simulate a problem with a thick pipe with anisotropic thermal properties and a single fluid core. The issue is the THM module by default adds isotropic heat conduction kernels for the 3d structure. In my case the pipe.
I did solve the issue by editing the source file of 'HeatStructureInterface.C' by adding a flag which when not true, allows me to add the desired anisotropic heat transfer kernels for the pipe.
I wanted to ask the community if there is another way of achieving the same which does not involve the source code alteration.
Thanks.

Hello
The current workflow is HeatStructureInterface creates a HeatConductionModel which creates the isotropic heat conduction kernels.
This cannot be changed at the moment.
We are however moving towards having a PhysicsInterface for components, which creates a Physics (see https://mooseframework.inl.gov/syntax/Physics/index.html)
and there you can create your own "heat conduction physics" which would be anisotropic. The existing one is not
An anisotropic option to the existing heat conduction physics would be a welcome contribution
Guillaume

node.title: Save the elastic energy density at each nodal as a auxvariable and then transfer it into subapp.
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I try to implement the phase field fracture model via multiapp method. In the main app, the elastic problem is solved and then I want to save the elastic energy density at each nodal in a aux variable, so that the aux variable is finally transferred into the phase field app.
My question is that how can I save the elastic energy density calculated by  ComputeCrackedStress as a aux variable correctly?

Hello
Is it a material property? You can project material properties onto auxiliary variables using auxkernels. This one for "Real" valued material properties
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/MaterialRealAux.html
there is a different auxkernel for every type of material property
Auxvariables can then be transferred. Note that you will suffer a projection error most likely between the material property and the auxiliary variable, unless the material property is actually represented exactly in the target finite element basis
Guillaume

Hi GiudGiud
Thanks for your reply. Actually I've used 'MaterialRealAux'. The code is like
[AuxVariables]
  [elastic_energy]
   order = FIRST
   family = MONOMIAL
  []
[]
[AuxKernels]
 [elastic_energy]
  type = MaterialRealAux
  variable = elastic_energy
  property = elastic_energy
 []
[]

However, this elastic_energy seems to return a volume-averaged quantity over the element. I think  what I need in a phase field fracture model is the strain energy density at each nodal or Gaussian point (if I'm not wrong). So how can I transfer them to the phase field app?

for nodal points use a nodal variable, like a first order lagrange.
For Gaussian points, what I mentioned above applies. You project the material property to a variable, then one can evaluate that variable at the Gauss points. They will only match rigorously if the projection step was exact because the material property was actually represented exactly by the finite element family & order you picked for the auxvariable

When I try to set elastic_energy as a first order lagrange variable, I receive the following errors.
Nodal AuxKernel 'elastic_energy' attempted to reference material property 'property'  Consider using an elemental auxiliary variable for 'elastic_energy'
I don't know why it happens. How can I fix it?

material properties are not defined at nodes.
So a direct projection wont be possible. You can try to make this work
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/auxkernels/ProjectedMaterialPropertyNodalPatchRecoveryAux.html
otherwise you can project onto a higher order monomial first, then use the ProjectionAux to project again onto a nodal variable
There's no real reason to use a nodal variable here imo, since material properties are using on quadrature points inside the element not at nodes

Yes, you're right! Thanks a lot!
But I still don't know if it is possible to transfer the positive part of the elastic strain energy density at the quadrature points. I think that's what I really need. Can I implement that in the present Transfer system?
Transferring material properties directly, not going through an auxiliary variable, would be a lot of work

node.title: Problems when installing MOOSE offline
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 I have consulted the Posting Guidelines.
 I have searched the Discussions Forum and MOOSE Framework Troubleshooting and have not found what I was looking for
 Q&A Getting Started is the most appropriate category for my question (trouble installing, beginner user, ...)

Issue or question about MOOSE
I followed the official offline installation guide and successfully built the PETSc library, but encountered issues when building the Libmesh library. I'm wondering if I might not have correctly understood the guide. Do I also need to manually download the dependencies required by Libmesh? I only downloaded the dependencies needed for PETSc using the ./scripts/update_and_rebuild_petsc.sh --CC=$CC --CXX=$CXX --FC=$FC --with-packages-download-dir=~/projects/downloads command and then directly ran the ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --skip-submodule-update command.
Ethan
(Optional) code in question / simulation log / errors
No response
Encountering Errors? Please include diagnostic output
No response

Hello
When you download moose before going offline, this part git submodule foreach --recursive git submodule update --init should have taken care of downloading all the libmesh dependencies
OK. I previously encountered network issues and didn't succeed, but now it's been stuck at Cloning into '/home/ethan/projects/moose/large_media'... for a long time. Is this normal?

that one is a little slow it s a big folder
you also dont need it unless you are building documentation

@GiudGiud OK. I've already downloaded the packages and got the offline.tar.gz
But when I build the libmesh, I got the error:
checking for the flags needed to use pthreads... -pthread
configure: /vexcl/vexcl.hpp not found
configure: /include/vexcl/vexcl.hpp not found
checking whether we are using the Microsoft C++ compiler... no
checking for CL/cl.h... no
checking for OpenCL/cl.h... no
checking for windows.h... no
checking for OpenCL library... no
checking for boost/system/error_code.hpp... yes
checking for the Boost system library... no
configure: error: cannot find flags to link with the Boost system library (libboost-system)
configure: error: ../../../contrib/metaphysicl/configure failed for contrib/metaphysicl
Running make -j 6...
make: *** No targets specified and no makefile found.  Stop.

The config is here:
config.log
And when I run the diagnostics.sh, it goes like:
################################################################################################
Python Sanity Checks

/usr/bin/env python3 --version; (reporting as: Python 3.11.1) matches
which python3 python;

/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/Python-3.11.1/build/bin/python3 --version; == Python 3.11.1
Python 2.7.5
FAIL: Python 2.7.5
/usr/bin/python --version (reporting as )) != Python 3.11.1

This will likely result in the TestHarness failing. Or WASP/HIT parsing errors.
################################################################################################
Python Modules (TestHarness, run-ability)

OK


checks FAILED

I'm not sure if the libmesh fail is because of the python version.
I can't access the /usr/bin, so how can I tell MOOSE to use the python 3.11.1 to build libmesh?
Ethan

you could alias python to python3
if you go in libmesh/contrib/metaphyscl what do you see?
is there a config.log there? because I dont see much in the libmesh one
and can you configure?

Yes I've used alias like: alias python='/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/Python-3.11.1/build/bin/python3'
So, I don't need to refer to the Python check results in the shell script, right?
And I can configure in libmesh/contrib/metaphyscl:

here is the config.log:
config.log

it exits with code 1 so it failed to configure in metaphyscl
the error is
configure:35683: error: cannot find flags to link with the Boost system library (libboost-system)

I wonder if there is an option to get boost from libmesh or petsc. Your system boost seems to not work

[hpc4123303047@ln08 metaphysicl]$ yum list installed | grep boost
boost.x86_64                           1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-atomic.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-chrono.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-context.x86_64                   1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-date-time.x86_64                 1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-devel.x86_64                     1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-filesystem.x86_64                1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-graph.x86_64                     1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-iostreams.x86_64                 1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-locale.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-math.x86_64                      1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-program-options.x86_64           1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-python.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-random.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-regex.x86_64                     1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-serialization.x86_64             1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-signals.x86_64                   1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-system.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-test.x86_64                      1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-thread.x86_64                    1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-timer.x86_64                     1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
boost-wave.x86_64                      1.53.0-27.el7                   @anaconda
ibus-typing-booster.noarch             1.2.3-4.el7                     @anaconda
My system has the Boost library installed, but I'm still encountering issues. How should I resolve this?
Perhaps I could try downloading a fresh copy of the boost library?

That sounds like a good idea. In libmesh you can change the configure call to use a different boost.
You'll have to add those arguments to moose/scripts/configre_libmesh.sh if you go that route
  --with-boost[=ARG]      use Boost library from a standard location
  --with-boost-libdir=LIB_DIR
                          Force given directory for boost libraries. Note that
                          fails and you know exactly where your boost

@GiudGiud Hello Giud. I'm still stuck in this problem. I've installed the boost_1_85_0 from source. And in the bashrc file I set:
export CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH=/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/boost_1_85_0/build/include:$CPLUS_INCLUDE_PATH
export LIBRARY_PATH=/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/boost_1_85_0/build/lib:$LIBRARY_PATH
export LD_LIBRARY_PATH=/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/boost_1_85_0/build/lib:$LD_LIBRARY_PATH

But the same errors appear when configuring:
checking for the Boost system library... no
configure: error: cannot find flags to link with the Boost system library (libboost-system)

Do you have any suggestions or good ideas on how to solve this issue? Thank you.
Ethan

My fault. Sry for that. I just realize that the config.log is changed.
Here is the new one:
config.log
@milljm I noticed that there's --prefix=/usr/local in it. But I can't access /usr/local. Could this be the source of the problem？

I was just going to report that, yes. Everything looked fine up until the contribs began to config.
Add a prefix argument:
--prefix=/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/libmesh
(just a guess as to where you want libmesh). Basically, I would place it right along side where ever you installed PETSc.
Where ever the location you pick, you'll want to then set LIBMESH_DIR= to point to this location, when you eventually get to the step of building MOOSE.
So all in all, in the end (if the above works):
export PETSC_DIR=/some/path/to/where/you/installed/petsc
export LIBMESH_DIR=/home/hpc4123303047/ZXY/MOOSE/packages/libmesh
cd ~/projects/moose/test
make
Edit: UGH... I always forget WASP :) You'll need to build WASP, and then set WASP_DIR= much in the same way above. And then you can build MOOSE.
Could it be an issue with libboost_system-mt.so? I noticed that it appears multiple times in the config.log, but I don't see this file in my boost/build/lib folder.
The problem is solved. I use ./configure --help to check the rules of the metaphysic's configuration. I should use --with--boost=/root/to/boost. And it succeeds. Thank you all :)
so you had to configure metaphysicl individually? The boost options did not propagate from libmesh?

No, I was just saying that I discovered the issue when compiling metaphysic separately. When I used the shell script ./update_and_rebuild_libmesh.sh --skip-submodule-update with the --with-boost option, I successfully compiled libMesh, and I also successfully installed MOOSE and passed the tests.
Thank you all :)
Ethan

node.title: add_subdomain_ids and Exodus output
node.bodyText:
Check these boxes if you have followed the posting rules.

 Q&A General is the most appropriate section for my question
 I have consulted the posting Guidelines on the Discussions front page
 I have searched the Discussions forum and my question has not been asked before
 I have searched the MOOSE website and the documentation does not answer my question
 I have formatted my post following the posting guidelines (screenshots as a last resort, triple back quotes around pasted text)

Question
Hello,
I am using add_subdomain_ids to add an empty subdomain (see below code). I need this for my simulations which start off with empty subdomains and have elements later added to them.
When I turn on the Exodus output, I get the below error. If the variable isn't MONOMIAL and CONSTANT, then this error won't appear. The same problem occurs if I use add_subdomain_names. I'm not sure if I did something wrong with the setup, or if you can't have an Exodus output for this particular setup.
Thank you.
Wendy

[Problem]
  solve = false
[]

[Mesh]
  [generated]
    type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
    dim = 2
    nx = 10
    ny = 10
  []
  add_subdomain_ids = 1
[]

[Variables]
  [dummy]
    family = MONOMIAL
    order = CONSTANT
    block = '0 1'
  []
[]

[Preconditioning]
  [SMP]
    type = SMP
    full = true
  []
[]

[Executioner]
  type = Transient
  end_time = 2
[]

[Outputs]
  exodus = True
[]

hello
this is a known issue, you need to actually have an element in subdomain 1 before outputting to exodus (for now)
Guillaume
Oh, I guess I haven't run into the problem before because I've been using the default family/order for variables, and that outputs to exodus fine. Is it going to be fixed?

We have no investigated it further.
We could remove the non-existing block from the element data before sending it to the exodus writer. That would be fine imo but it s a little hacky. The better fix is in libmesh, modifying write_element_data to not die on missing subdomains
Should I create an issue over there? Or do you have better connections with the guys there?
Sure
Please find the issue with libmesh here: libMesh/libmesh#3949
